race.name: Rasputitsa
race.tagline: Vermont's early season mud fest—46 miles of Class 4 roads, self-supported suffering, and guaranteed mud.

climate.description: 35-55°F, 40% rain chance, mud guaranteed. 'Rasputitsa' = Russian for 'mud season'.

terrain.surface: 70% dirt roads, 20% gravel, 10% pavement. Class 4 roads = unmaintained. April = mud. Self-supported (NO aid stations). 5,000 ft elevation over 46 miles. Technical rating: 4/5.

biased_opinion.summary: Rasputitsa is Vermont's early season mud fest—46 miles of Class 4 roads (unmaintained dirt), 5,000 ft elevation, self-supported (NO aid stations), and guaranteed mud. Founded 2016, 10th anniversary 2026. 'Rasputitsa' is Russian for 'mud season'. April in Vermont = mud. Class 4 roads = technical. Self-supported = hardcore. 600+ riders. Burke Northeast Kingdom. If you want Vermont hardcore suffering, this is it. If you want smooth gravel and aid stations, run away.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: Rasputitsa is Vermont mud masochism. If you want technical Class 4 roads, self-supported adventure, and guaranteed mud, this is bucket-list. If you want smooth gravel and support, skip it. Mud is the point. Embrace it or stay home.

logistics.lodging_note: Burke small Northeast Kingdom town. Book early. Limited lodging.
logistics.travel_summary: Burlington airport 50 miles. Rental car needed. Burke small town—book lodging early. Day-before packet pickup. Race Saturday.
logistics.food_options: NONE on course (self-supported). Post-race party at finish.

course_description.character: 46 miles of Vermont Class 4 roads (unmaintained dirt). 5,000 ft elevation. Self-supported (NO aid). Mud guaranteed (April). Technical rating: 4/5.

suffering_zones.name: Throughout: Class 4 Roads + Mud
suffering_zones.description: Unmaintained dirt roads. April mud guaranteed. Bikes clog. Technical.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: 40-50mm tires. Aggressive tread. Carry spares. Accept mud. Pace conservatively.

suffering_zones.name: Mile 20-40: Burke Mountain Area
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Low gears. Walk if needed. Self-supported means manage energy.

suffering_zones.name: Self-Supported: All Miles
suffering_zones.description: NO aid stations. Carry food, water, spares. Bonk = DNF.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Carry 2+ bottles, food for 4-6 hours, spare tube, CO2, multitool.

course_description.signature_challenge: April mud + self-supported + Class 4 technical roads. Mud is guaranteed, aid is not.

history.origin_story: Rasputitsa founded 2016. Named for Russian word meaning 'mud season'. Vermont early season mud fest. 600+ riders. Burke Northeast Kingdom. Self-supported. 10th anniversary 2026.
history.reputation: Vermont hardcore mud fest. Self-supported. Grassroots.

logistics.explanation: Adam Roberge describes 'one of the craziest' starts he's ever raced, featuring '3km downhill, weaving in and out of a golf path with two long and deep mudslides.' Jay Peak Resort hosting solves some basics, but Heidi Myers admits 'a lot of calls cannot be made until the last minute' regarding course conditions and bike choice—that's either charming spontaneity or operational chaos.

length.explanation: Adam Roberge won in 2:45 with a TSS of 357, burning 5,971 calories over what he lists as 88km (55 miles). Chris Hadgis jokes his 'running time would be very close to my biking time,' but admits 'for a trail runner moonlighting as a cyclist getting across the finish line is a big deal.' Short enough that elite winners are done before lunch.

technicality.explanation: The Cyberia section features 'unmaintained roads' that 'are not plowed, they don't lay sand, they're not salted' with 'extensive snow cover' where 'you can see people literally walking their bikes through.' Chris Hadgis rode 'that shit on my mountain bike' while others debate fat bikes versus cyclocross. Adam St. Germain warns 'every bike is the wrong bike.'

elevation.explanation: Chris Hadgis describes climbing that 'felt like it never ended. Seriously. If you want to challenge your climbing legs get up here. It's a BEAST. My granny gear and I hung out together all day.' Adam Roberge's final climb was 'a 20-25 minute effort through very loose and muddy conditions' with 4,900 feet over 41 miles in 2019.

climate.explanation: 2019 delivered 'hail at the start, snow on the course, downpour of rain—pretty much all the shit you could possibly imagine' with ~200 DNFs from hypothermia. 2016 was 'dry, sunny, high of 60' while 2024 had 'deep mud and occasional snow.' Lea Davison called it 'the second hardest thing I've ever done' after La Ruta in Costa Rica.

altitude.explanation: Burke, Vermont sits at typical New England elevations with no altitude considerations. The suffering comes from weather, mud, and gradient—not thin air.

adventure.explanation: Heidi Myers admits 'I saw people out there who just broke down mentally' dealing with weather conditions. The race offers a money-back guarantee: 'Not hard enough for you? Rasputitsa will return your entry fee. Thus far, everyone has gone home happy.' That's confidence in delivering authentic misery through Vermont's mud season lottery.

prestige.explanation: Ten years in and CycloWorld calls it 'legendary,' but let's be honest—this isn't Unbound. Rasputitsa draws 1,500 riders for the finish line party, which puts it in solid regional tier, not national spotlight. The race gets featured in bucket list articles, but I don't see pro riders or major sponsors throwing money at Burke, Vermont.

race_quality.explanation: Heidi Myers knows racers 'by name' and can 'walk up to about half the people who attend and say Hey Jen.' When hypothermia hit in 2019, 'we had eight vehicles on course just picking up riders' at feed zones. Personal touch is strong, but last-minute course decisions and weather-dependent execution create operational uncertainty.

experience.explanation: Chris Hadgis describes aid stations with 'rainbow-colored, grinning unicorns' offering 'homemade chocolate chip cookies' and 'maple syrup shots in tiny little shot glasses made of ice.' Post-race includes AC/DC cover bands, gravel confessional booths, and hair-do stations. Pearl Jam tribute band performances frame a multi-day festival atmosphere.

community.explanation: The race philosophy states 'the largest award goes to the Lanterne Rouge recipient'—last finisher wins biggest prize. All proceeds support Little Bellas mentoring program, raising $19,000+ annually. When Anthony Moccia faced cancer, the community rallied with benefit concerts. Chris Hadgis praises volunteers as 'cheerful, supportive, out there spending their day helping crazy bike riders.'

field_depth.explanation: 1,500 cyclists shows up for the party, but there's zero intel on who's actually racing fast. No mention of pro riders, no winner history, no competitive depth data in 10 years of race reports. This feels like a participation festival where everyone's racing their own demons more than each other.

value.explanation: Myers emphasizes 'modest price tag of early-day gravel' with founders explicitly 'not using this construct to make money.' Multi-day festival includes live music, ice shot glasses of maple syrup, and post-race spreads at Burke Publick House. All entry fees go toward charity rather than profit margins.

expenses.explanation: Jay Peak Resort hosting means lodging exists but likely isn't budget-friendly during race weekend. Burke, Vermont requires driving from Boston or Burlington airports. Equipment debates between mountain bikes, fat bikes, and gravel setups could require specific gear purchases depending on conditions—Heidi Myers notes riders asking 'Should I bring my fat bike?'

final_verdict.one_liner: Vermont's 10-year-old mud lottery where 5,000 feet of climbing meets April's bipolar weather and your cross training actually matters.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you can handle 46 miles of sustained climbing in conditions that range from perfect to apocalyptic, Rasputitsa delivers authentic Northeast Kingdom suffering without the ego. The 5,000 feet of elevation isn't negotiable, and April weather means you might get snow, mud, or sunshine—sometimes all three. Skip this if you need predictable conditions or hate climbing.
final_verdict.alternatives: Vermont Overland offers similar Vermont grit with more distance options, while Dirty Kanza (Unbound) gives you comparable difficulty without the elevation. For pure climbing punishment, try Gravel Worlds if you want the suffering with better weather odds.
